title: Week 5
text:
Class slides



1:00 - 1:10 : Questions & check-in
1:10 - 2:10: Git branching
2:10 - 2:15: BREAK
2:15 - 2:55: DIP Data Management peer review
2:55 - 3:00: BREAK
3:00 - 3:50: Testing
3:50 - 3:55: DIP Executive Summary
3:55 - 4:00: Checklist for next class





Submit by 5pm on Friday 2/9 your complete DIP draft:

Incorporate the feedback you’ve received so far.
Send an email to your advisor and me with a link to you google doc.
Make the most out of this revision: it’s great to request specific feedback from your advisor! Is there any section you’d particularly like their input on? Let them know in your message. You can also tag us in comments inside your document.
Page limit: The Design and Implementation plan should be limited to 10 single-spaced pages of written text. This page limit does not include the title page, executive summary, graphics and figures, budget and justification, or references cited.




Prepare 4 slides covering:

Slide 1: A cover slide
Slide 2: Brief overview of project’s products and deliverables (don’t include academic ones) and which ones you are currently working on.
Slide 3: An update or two on the progress you’ve made on the deliverables. Include code, graphs, or figures your team has generated. Explain how this work will integrate with or is a step towards your deliverable.
Slide 4: Next steps.

Pick a person or two who are ready to do a 3 minute presentation next class. Add slides to Week 6 - Flash talks.
Focus on:

Switching “Shiny app” for “interactive web app” or “dashboard”
Avoiding big blocks of text.
Clearly explaining the figures you feature (see class slides) and adding references and provenance where appropriate.
Professional presentation.
Seamless transitions between sections, clear, and precise speech.
Practice and time it!




Go to https://learngitbranching.js.org/ and do the (short) exercises in these sections:

Main: introduction sequence and Ramping Up
Remote: Push & Pull – Git Remotes!

title: Week 6
text:
Class slides
Faculty Review Logistics - Emily Case
Ten Ways to Improve Presentations - Alex Phillips, PhD



1:00 - 1:10 : Questions & check-in
1:10 - 1:55 : Flash presentations
1:55 - 2:00: BREAK
2:00 - 3:30: Public Speaking Workshop - Dr. Alex Phillips, NCEAS, AAAS Fellow
3:30 - 3:35: BREAK
3:35 - 3:55: Faculty Review Logistics - Emily Case, Bren School
3:55 - 4:00: Checklist for next class






Read these guidelines for your presentation.
Decide with your team what preliminary results, progress, or prototype you will include in your presentation
Put together a complete draft slide deck following Alex’s presentation, point 6. It’s ok if you add stand-in figures for prototypes or preliminary results for now. Focus on the story line.
Discuss your draft slides with your faculty advisor. They know the details about your project.
Decide who will be presenting in faculty review (and who in public final presentation). Every person in the team should be ready to present if needed.
Add your draft slides to our shared drive and be ready to do a formal mock presentation next week!

Additional considerations:

Slides must be Google slides.
Do not include any text (in images, plots, diagrams, etc) too small to read
Do not include code screenshots: think about effective ways to convey your progress.
Remember your audience: disciplinary experts with varying data science familiarity who will give you feedback about your objectives, approach, and methods.

Practice:

Everything on Alex’s workshop!
Professional presentation: posture, tone, and clear speech
Using your memory (no notes)
Projecting your voice
Clearly explaining plots, graphs, and diagrams
Timing it: 12 minutes no more, no less
Having your team join you at the end for questions and feedback




If you have already received feedback from your advisor:

discuss feedback with your team
start working on updating your draft
contact advisors or clients for clarification and reply to comments within the document as needed. Remember to always do your research and discuss with your team first!

title: Week 6
text:
Class Slides
Faculty Review Logistics Slides




1:00 - 1:05: Upcoming assignments
1:05 - 1:35: Faculty Review Logistics - Emily Case & Allie Caughman
1:35 - 2:00: 2023 MEDS capstone final presentation screening
2:00 - 3:45: Dedicated work time & meetings with teams
3:45 - 4:00: Closing round










Incorporate the feedback you’ve received so far.
Send an email to your advisor and me with a link to you google doc and a link to your project’s GitHub organization/ project repo.
Use this checklist to guide you through cleaning your repo.
Be professional, thank them in advance for their feedback.
Make the most out of this revision: it’s great to request specific feedback from your advisor! Is there any section you’d particularly like their input on? Let them know in your message. You can also tag us in comments inside your document.




Abstract: Prepare and send for revision to your advisor

The abstract is a one-paragraph brief summary of the group project, meant for a non-technical audience. The length of the abstract should not exceed 200 words. It can be the same as the one in your technical documentation.
If your project title has changed, please include the new title in the abstract.
Your advisor must approve the final abstract and any title updates before submission.

Acknowledgments: Prepare and ask for consent from everyone listed

The acknowledgements should include advisors, professionals, organizations, funding sources, etc. that assisted the Capstone Project.
Each acknowledgment should include the person’s name, title (if known), and affiliation/organization.
You should obtain authorization from each person or party being acknowledged that their names can be included in the abstract.
Emily will send you more details about the format for the acknowledgements this week, but you should start collecting the names.

The abstract and acknowledgements are due on Friday, May 17 (next week).




Decide who will be presenting in the final public presentation. Remember every person in the team should be ready to present if needed.
Review the guidelines for your presentation covered today
Prepare a formal mock presentation (14 minutes long) for next Wednesday


Strongly suggest following Alex’s presentation, point 6 to prepare your slides.
The presentation design considerations from last quarter still apply.
It’s ok if you add stand-in figures for prototypes and results for now.
Focus on the story line: this is a public presentation for a general audience.


Discuss your draft slides with your faculty advisor.
Add your draft to our shared drive and be ready to do present next week!

title: Week 2
text:
Slides



1:00 - 1:05: Questions & check-in
1:05 - 1:40: Flash talks
1:40 - 2:15: Peer feedback of Technical Documentation outline
2:15 - 2:20: Upcoming assignments
2:20 - 3:45: Dedicated work time & meetings with teams
3:45 - 4:00: Closing round









Submit by 1pm on Wednesday 4/10
Submit an expanded version of your TD outline by 1 pm on Wednesday 4/17. Add your document to our shared folder Week 3 - TD Outline submission.
The outline should include: 1. Problem statement 2. Revised project objectives 3. Summary of solution design 4. Products and deliverables 5. Summary of testing 6. User documentation 7. Archive access 8. References 9. Appendices
For each section:

include as much information as completed to date
note the extent to which the section is completed and any remaining obstacles to its completion.

As an appendix to the outline:

describe the work to be completed during the remainder of Spring Quarter
include a timeline for remaining tasks and deliverables.

We’ll have a round of peer feedback on this document next week.

Please book a time to meet in my calendar.
What: a short (~10 minute) meetings with each of you to check how things are going. My goal is to provide feedback and guidance and identify any issues early on.
When: Week 6, April 29 - May 2
Where: Monday & Wednesday @ NCEAS, Tuesday & Thursday @ Bren

title: Week 3
text:
Class slides



1:00 - 1:15 : Questions & check-in
1:15 - 1:55: GitHub organization & projects
2:55 - 2:00: BREAK
2:00 - 2:50: git merge conflicts
2:50 - 3:00: BREAK
3:00 - 3:40: DIP Solution Design
3:40 - 3:54: DIP Timelines & Milestones
3:50 - 3:55: ABT elevator pitch
3:55 - 4:00: Checklist for next class





Draft of DIP Approach & Methods section and DIP Proposed Software & Tools section
Include your workflow diagram draft (a screenshot is ok). In your final DIP this should become a finalized figure with an overview of your project’s workflow. Add document to the shared folder Week 3 - Approach & Methods / Proposed Software or Tools.
There might be details, questions, or even gaps about how you’ll create your deliverables. Start filling those in. First step is always to research, brainstorm, and clarify with your team. Then, as needed, reach out to your advisor or client with questions or options.
Draft of DIP Timeline & Milestones
Include a Gantt Chart to visualize represent your project’s timeline. Some Gantt chart resources from Casey O’Hara. You can also make a nice looking one in Google sheets.
Timeline should include client’s and academic deliverables, and appropriate intermediate deliverables leading to the project’s completion
Add document to the shared folder Week 3 - Timeline & Milestones.




Prepare 4 slides covering:

Slide 1: A cover slide

Slide 2: Your ABT elevator pitch telling us what your project is about (<< 1 min)
Slide 3: Brief overview of project’s products and deliverables
Slide 4: Approach and methods draft diagram

Pick a person or two who are ready to do a 3 minute presentation next class Add slides to Week 4 - Flash talks before class.
Focus on:

Avoiding big blocks of text.
Seamless transitions between sections, clear, and precise speech.
Practice and time it!
Listen for every qualifier you use. “Kind of” “sort of” “I guess.” Avoid these!
When describing your workflow diagram, practice curious statements. Instead of “We have no idea how we’re going to do this part,” what can you say?





Update:

Your GitHub organization’s landing page to include the project summary you submitted a on week 2. Delete all the repositories, issues, and projects from this week’s demo sessions.
If your team plans to use GitHub issues, milestones, and projects to track progress or allocate tasks (highly encouraged), update your team management plan sections V and VI to include these. Then create some issues, milestones, and a project to track the bigger steps of your Approach & Methods section.





Read the Data Management Plan section of the MEDS Capstone Project Guidelines (1 page). Next week we’ll have a presentation by the Research Data Services from UCSB’s Library. Come prepared with questions about data management and archival for your project.

title: Week 1
text:
Slides



1:00 - 1:30 : Overview of EDS 411, Capstone Project, and DIP
1:30 - 2:00: Client relations workshop - Miya Scheble, Bren School
2:00 - 2:05: BREAK
2:05 - 3:00: Communication roles activity
3:00 - 3:10: BREAK
3:10 - 3:50: Capstone project group roles, alias, and summary
3:50 - 4:00: Checklist for next class





Goals for first client meeting (to be held before next class):
☑️ Clarify what the objectives are (if you have any questions - know what they are before the meeting)
☑️ Address any issue with accessing data (determine beforehand what these might be)
☑️ Find out who the audience for your product will be and if there will be people who can test it
Before meeting the client meeting, develop an agenda, including:

who will be the meeting facilitator/chair and who will take notes
agenda (with times)
list of clarifying questions you want to ask the client
any questions about the data - make sure you know how to access it

After meeting: reflect with your team on how it went and what could be improved.




Read:
☑️ MEDS Capstone Project Guidelines, available at Bren’s Academic Resources webste
☑️ Sample DIPs
☑️ Ten simple rules to cultivate belonging in collaborative data science research teams
Prepare with your capstone team 3 slides covering:

An ultra summarized version of what your capstone project will do
The datasets you’ll use
 One graph showing exploratory visualization of your data

Pick a person or two who are ready to do a 3 minute presentation next. class




Submit by 5pm on Tuesday 1/16: Project roles. Update them on the EDS 2024 Capstone Assignments
Submit by 5pm on Friday 1/19: Finalize your summary paragraph for Bren website, add to Capstone Summaries.  Your advisor must review your summary before submitting it.

Updating your DIP:

add details about your project your team has gathered while preparing for faculty reviews
got a cool diagram that succinctly describes your process or model? consider adding it to your DIP

Getting your preliminary results or creating a prototype for review




Have a mock presentation with your faculty advisor. Prioritize their feedback.
Make sure you are ready to explain any technical terms you mention in your presentation.
I might send you some extra comments and feedback
Practice! That is half the battle.
If you would like to iterate once more with me, you’re welcome to schedule a 30 minute block on my calendar on Friday (Manzanita room) or Monday morning (Sequoia room).




Emily will send an email with important reminders next Monday. Meanwhile, review the following documents:

title: Overview
text:
Welcome to the course materials for EDS 411A - MEDS Capstone! This course is part of the UCSB Masters in Environmental Data Science at the Bren School of Environmental Science and Mananagement.
In this website you will find the materials covered during lectures for the Winter 2024 term.



The goal of EDS 411A is to facilitate student learning, work, and progress on their MEDS Capstone project through lessons, activities, supervised and unsupervised project work, and peer review and feedback. Additionally, EDS 411A provides opportunities for professional and career development (e.g. presentation skills, writing and editing, client relations, team science, panel discussions, and conflict resolution).



Click here to view syllabus.



Carmen Galaz García
Pronouns: she/her/hers
E-mail: c_galazgarcia@ucsb.edu
Office hour: by appointmnet, Zoom or NCEAS classroom
Best way to contact me: e-mail, Slack



The following is our ideal calendar, the course content may be subject to change as the course progresses.

title: EDS 411: MEDS Capstone Courses
text:
Welcome to the course materials for MEDS Capstone Courses EDS 411A and EDS 411B! This course sequence is part of the UCSB Masters in Environmental Data Science at the Bren School of Environmental Science and Mananagement.
In this website you will find the materials covered during lectures for the 2024 Winter and Spring terms. This site will be under construction throughout the course.


The goal of MEDS Capstone Courses EDS 411A and EDS 411B is to facilitate student learning, work, and progress on their MEDS Capstone project through lessons, activities, supervised and unsupervised project work, and peer review and feedback. Additionally, these courses provides opportunities for professional and career development (e.g. presentation skills, writing and editing, client relations, team science, panel discussions, and conflict resolution).



Carmen Galaz García (she/her/hers)
E-mail: c_galazgarcia@ucsb.edu
Best way to contact me: e-mail, Slack



This website is created with Quarto and is published through GitHub pages. Click here to go to the website’s GitHub repository.

Additionally, these courses provides opportunities for professional and career development (e.g. presentation skills, writing and editing, client relations, team science, panel discussions, and conflict resolution).

title: Week 2
text:
📕 Class slides
📗 Computing resources slides
📘 Conflict resolution workshop slides



1:00 - 1:10 : Questions and check-in
1:10 - 1:45 : Flash presentations
1:45 - 2:00 : Computing resources presentation - Kat Le, Bren School
2:00 - 2:05: BREAK
2:05 - 3:20: Conflict resolution workshop - Amelia Liberatore, NCEAS
3:20 - 3:25: BREAK
3:25 - 3:55: Co-working on project statement and objectives
3:55 - 4:00: Checklist for next class





Submit by 5pm on Friday 1/19:
Finalize your summary paragraph for Bren website, add to Capstone Summaries.  Your advisor must review your summary before submitting it. 
Submit by 5pm on Tuesday 1/23:
Draft of DIP Team Management Plan section. Add document to the shared folder Week 2 - Team Management Plan draft.
Consider the following resources when writing the Team Management Plan:

MEDS Capstone Project Guidelines
Team’s project roles and responsibilities
Ten simple rules to cultivate belonging in collaborative data science research teams
Flexible communication roles among team members
Conflict resolution strategies
Dr. Allison Horst’s Code of Conduct

Submit by 5pm on Tuesday 1/23:
Draft of DIP Problem Statement and Objectives Section and DIP Products & Deliverables Add document to the shared folder Week 2 - Problem & Objectives / Deliverables
Remember:

your team is responsible for reaching out to your client or advisor with any questions needed to clarify these sections
as needed, you can seek feedback from your advisor on your DIP sections before submitting a complete first draft on 2/9.

title: Week 7
text:
Class slides
Responding to questions slides










I might send you some extra comments and feedback after class
Incorporate the feedback and streamline your presentation
Iterate with your faculty advisor
Practice makes perfect. :-)





Go over this presentation about best practices to answer questions about your presentation.
Identify 4 - 5 bins that you expect faculty review questions to fall into (e.g. model selection, data management, statistical analyses). Write them down.
Brainstorm who would be most appropriate to respond to questions in each bin.
Write down 2 - 3 questions in each bin that you might expect (and/or are afraid of getting) during your faculty review Prepare, if necessary, any extra slides you might need during your Q&A





Updating your DIP: all DIPs need more details about their main deliverable
Getting your preliminary results or creating a prototype for review











This is an optional event to prepare for your MEDS Faculty Reviews.



What: watching two recordings of previous MEDS faculty reviews
When: Thursday, February 22, 3:15 - 4:15
Where: At Bren, room 1414
Who: everyone in MEDS can come and will benefit from it! This is an optional event and it will be especially beneficial if you couldn’t make it to MESM presentations.

title: Overview
text: The following is our ideal calendar, the course content may be subject to change as the course progresses.

title: Week 1
text:
Slides



1:00 - 2:15 : Overview of EDS 411B, Spring Quarter deliverables, Technical Documentation, Checklist for next class
2:15 - 3:45: Dedicated work time & meetings with teams
3:45 - 4:00: Closing round









Submit by 1pm on Wednesday 4/10.
Create a single Google doc with the following information:

A detailed list of the sections (table of contents) your team will have in their Technical Documentation.

Specify who is the audience for each section or group of sections.
Explain what kind of user documentation you will create. Have a clear description of who the “user” for the document will be. Discuss this with your advisor.

A timeline to completion for your Technical Documentation taking into account the capstone deadlines. Consider making a Gantt chart, but also a list of dates and deliverables is ok. Tips:

If you liked how we split up the DIP by sections per week, try implementing something similar.
Write your executive summary and abstract last, your project might evolve along the quarter.


Add your document to our shared folder TD Outlines and Timeline.



Prepare 4 slides covering:

Slide 1: A cover slide introducing your team
Slide 2: Your ABT elevator pitch telling us what your project is about (~ 40 s) Write down your elevator pitch on the slide.
Slide 3: Brief overview of project’s products and deliverables
Slide 4: Brief overview of your user documentation section: what it will be about and who is the target audience.

Pick a person or two who are ready to do a ~3 minute presentation next class
Add slides to shared folder Week 2 - Flash talks.

This is an informal presentation to get us back up to speed and introduce your projects to our TA.
Make sure your elevator pitch reflects the current objectives of your project, update it if needed.
Make sure your elevator pitch is crisp, short, and follows the ABT structure.
You should reuse, if possible, any slides you made last quarter.





Revise the timeline you submitted in your DIP: are you on time to complete it?
Revise and discuss your updated timeline with your advisor.
Update your client on any significant changes.

title: Week 4
text:
Slides



1:00 - 1:15: Questions & check-in
1:15 - 1:20: Upcoming assignments
1:20 - 3:45: Dedicated work time & meetings with teams
3:45 - 4:00: Closing round









Please book a time to meet in my calendar.
What: a short (~10 minute) meetings with each of you to check how things are going. My goal is to provide feedback and guidance and identify any issues early on.
When: Week 6, April 29 - May 2
Where: Monday & Wednesday @ NCEAS, Tuesday & Thursday @ Bren



If you have already received feedback from your advisor:

discuss feedback with your team
start working on updating your draft
contact advisors or clients for clarification and reply to comments within the document as needed. Remember to always do your research and discuss with your team first!

1:50 - 1:55: BREAK

2:25 - 2:30: BREAK
2:30 - 3:55: Data Management - Julien Brun, Reserach Data Services, UCSB Library
3:55 - 4:00: Checklist for next class





Context: your Team Management Plan + Deliverables submissions and flashtalks, and the feedback you received.
Add this point to your next team meeting agenda:
Discuss what went well and and what could be better. How will our team improve?

Is your team delivering high-quality work?
Do you need to re-read the capstone guidelines?
Should you seek more feedback or guidance from your - client/advisor?
Does your team need to share work earlier so everyone can revise?
Do you need to establish new expectations or ground rules in your team management plan?




A single-document draft of the DIP including:

Draft of DIP Solution Design - Data Management Plan and Documentation Plan sections
Updates for all other sections you’ve drafted so far
Title page, budget and budget justification, and references section
In summary: everything in the DIP except for the testing plan and executive summary

Add document to the shared folder Week 4 - DIP draft.











Allocate enough time discuss the Data Management Plan with your team and write it. This is one of the longer sections in the DIP.
Remember to always read the Capstone Guidelines first if you have questions about how to write any of the DIP sections!
Check the DIP length requirements in the Capstone Guidelines and start discussing with your team whether you’ll need to shorten it by 2/9.






We’ll have 1-1 meetings February 12-16 to check how everything is going. Please book a 15-minute slot to meet in my calendar.
Location: Manzanita room at NCEAS.

title: Week 10
text:
Class slides










Upload it to Box in PDF format with your Capstone Project short name (e.g., GaiaFuture Design and Implementation Plan.pdf).
Email to your faculty advisor and client: be professional and thank them for their involvement.





Enter a link to your project repository on this Google sheet. This can be a link to your Capstone project GitHub organization or a specific repository.





Each student must complete a Capstone Project Peer & Self Evaluation Form for Winter Quarter.
Upload your evaluation form to Box and save your document with your Capstone Project short name and your full name as the file name (e.g., SaferSeafood Emily Case).
You must also email your evaluation directly to your faculty advisor.





Addressing conflict workshop survey (5 minutes).
UCSB course survey (10 minutes): https://ucsb.bluera.com/ucsb
